title: Boris Johnson's toxic legacy means residents think they're being gassed at front door
text:

On the streets of London’s ­Southall, there is an overpowering chemical smell in the air.

A vast site that once included Southall Gasworks and a chemical factory is being developed for housing – and toxic soil has been disturbed.

More than 50 residents here complain of illnesses such as nausea, dizziness, respiratory conditions, high blood pressure and throat and eye infections.

Meanwhile, several ­residents diagnosed with cancer believe it is linked to the toxic ­chemicals in the soil.

Janet Griffiths, 49, describes living in the area, where there are three primary schools, as “like you are in a petrol station with the engine running”.

She says: “One night, I opened my front door to such a strong gas smell I actually thought someone was trying to gas me and I rang the police.”

This, many residents claim, is Prime Minister Boris Johnson ’s toxic legacy.

(Image: Adam Gerrard/Daily Mirror)

Back in 2010, when he was Mayor of London, Johnson used special powers to intervene to force the Southall Waterside development to go ahead.

This was against the views of the local authority, Ealing Council, and ­residents who were deeply worried after a report found a cocktail of chemicals in the ground including benzene, naphthalene, asbestos, arsenic and cyanide.

Now, campaigners from Clean Air for Southall and Hayes (CASH) are preparing legal action.

“This is another Grenfell waiting to happen, but nobody can see it because it is in the air,” Janet says.

“It’s ­frightening. My mum died of lung cancer in January 2018.

"Last year I started to get out of breath, even walking up the stairs. My GP sent me for an X-ray and I was told I had an enlarged heart.”

The 88 acres of land was purchased by Berkeley Group from the National Grid in 2013 as part of a £1billion development.

With a prized connection to Crossrail, Southall Waterside will include 3,750 homes and up to 500,000 sq ft of commercial space.

Contractors set up a “soil hospital” to clean up before ­construction could begin. But locals say it hasn’t protected them from the chemical effects.

Now, after two years of complaining to Ealing Council, Berkeley Group, the Environment Agency and Public Health England, ­residents are bringing legal action.

(Image: Andy Stenning / Daily Mirror)

Nina Bedi, 53, lives with her 79-year-old father, who was recently diagnosed with cancer. Their garden, which overlooks the ­development, is often covered with dust.

“My sister who lives abroad, came to stay with us for nine months,” she says. “In August she was ­diagnosed with bone marrow cancer.

"She’s 51. My question is, did these ­chemicals cause the cancers?”

Baphinder Athwal, 57, says his garden is covered with dust too. “I have had problems with my eyes, my blood pressure, and I’ve had heart palpitations. My family don’t like to visit because of the smell.”

Local mum Angela Fonso, 51, founded CASH. “Depending on the direction of the wind, some days are worse than others,” she says. “Some of the residents have now paid for ­monitoring devices and some of the data is alarming.”

Amrik Mahi, 56, is ­frightened. “One day, I was walking down the road and my chest felt like it was exploding,” he says.

“Yet when I leave the area, I’m fine. My daughter was here with my granddaughter and we went to the park, but the smell was too strong. I told them to go home, I am not having my granddaughter poisoned.”

A council spokesman said: “After concerns about odour from the Southall Waterside development we asked Public Health England (PHE) to carry out a report on possible health effects.

"Air quality monitoring is being reviewed by PHE and it has now published three reports which show that it is ‘unlikely that there is a direct toxicological risk to the long-term health of the nearby population’.

"We will continue to monitor the site and want to hear from anyone ­experiencing problems.”

A spokesman for Berkeley said: “Cleaning contaminated land is a highly regulated activity and all our work was monitored and approved by the authorities, including the London Borough of Ealing and the Environment Agency.

"Berkeley’s ­remediation work is now complete and cleaning this land has brought it into use for much-needed housing, including affordable homes for Ealing residents.”

Jo Sidhu QC, who grew up in Southall, is supporting CASH.

“When developers appealed to the Mayor of London in 2010, I attended the hearing and warned him the pollution threat would be catastrophic for the ­community’s health,” he says.

“But it felt like he had already made up his mind and he gave it the green light in a matter of minutes.

“This land is dangerous, it is contaminated with poisonous ­chemicals. In the last year my own mum, who lives close to the site, ­developed severe breathing problems that put her in hospital three times.

“We all know there are desperate housing shortages, but we can’t just build on poisoned brownfield sites without a care for the health of ­ordinary folk living nearby. It’s happening up and down the country.”

The legal action, he says, is a “David and Goliath battle which is literally a matter of life and death for working-class residents”.
description: Southall Gasworks and a chemical factory is being developed for housing after former mayor Johnson used special powers to push development through
